briefTitle: Does a Non-Opioid Multimodal Pain (NOMO) Protocol Decrease Narcotic Use
officialTitle: The Effect of a Non-Opioid Multimodal Pain (NOMO) Protocol in Decreasing Narcotic Use After Urogynecologic Surgery
summary: The objective of this study is to evaluate narcotic use after implementation of a Non-Opioid Multimodal Pain (NOMO) protocol in patients who are undergoing a urogynecologic procedure. The study will also evaluate secondary outcomes, including: post-operative pain rating, length of hospital stay, postoperative antiemetic use, bladder catheterization at discharge, number of post-operative phone calls, and rate of reported side effects of opioid use (nausea/constipation). Study participants will be asked to utilize the validated Brief Pain Inventory (appendix A) scale to assess post-operative pain levels. Based on inpatient post-operative opioid use and number of opioid pills prescribed at discharge, an attempt will be made to develop an algorithm for recommended opioid prescribing patterns.

primaryOutcome.measure: Morphine Milligram Equivalents Used During Inpatient Stay
primaryOutcome.timeFrame: from immediately postoperative through discharge or 4 weeks, whichever comes first
